metaphor.core: The core concept of 'Fight Club'—two distinct personalities coexisting within a single body, and the philosophical struggle with identity and control—serves as a metaphor for React Fragments. A React component must return a single root element, yet often needs to render multiple sibling elements. Fragments (`<>...</>`) allow these elements to be grouped without introducing an unnecessary wrapper DOM node, thereby maintaining a clean and semantically correct UI structure, akin to two personalities existing without a 'third man' container.

mapping.fictionElement: Two distinct personalities (Narrator and Tyler) in one body
mapping.reactConcept: Multiple adjacent JSX elements that a React component needs to return, but which must be wrapped in a single root element.
Using an extra `<div>` element to group multiple JSX elements, which adds an unnecessary DOM node to the component tree.

mapping.fictionElement: Breaks every layout it touches (e.g., flexbox)
mapping.reactConcept: The negative side effects of extra wrapper `<div>`s, particularly in CSS layouts like Flexbox or Grid, where an unexpected DOM node can disrupt styling and semantic structure.

mapping.fictionElement: The 'wrapper was a lie' / 'they were never separate'
mapping.reactConcept: `React.Fragment` (`<>...</>`): a special built-in component that lets you group children without adding extra nodes to the DOM.
The benefit of Fragments: grouping multiple elements cleanly without impacting the DOM structure or CSS layouts.
The elegance and efficiency of Fragments in maintaining a flat and semantically correct DOM tree.

metaphor.narrativeArc: The module starts by posing the core problem: rendering two elements when only one root is allowed, using the 'two personalities, one body' metaphor. It then introduces the problematic 'Third Man' (wrapper `div`), demonstrating how it breaks layouts. The revelation that 'the wrapper was a lie' leads to Fragments as the elegant solution. A clear comparison of 'one box vs. no box' solidifies the understanding, culminating in a 'clean structure' enabled by Fragments.

problems: JSX syntax error when returning multiple adjacent elements
Adding unnecessary wrapper `div` elements, leading to increased DOM node count
Disrupting CSS layouts (e.g., Flexbox, Grid) due to extra wrapper divs

chapters.title: The Third Man

chapters.title: The Wrapper Was a Lie
chapters.focus: Explains `React.Fragment` (`<>...</>`) as the solution for grouping multiple elements without adding extra DOM nodes.

chapters.title: One Box vs. No Box

chapters.title: A Clean Structure
chapters.focus: Summarizes the advantages of Fragments for creating efficient, semantic, and maintainable React component structures.
